div.head: A Letter from Holland, relating the Designes of the Scotch Presbyter, together with the Usage of their King, being an Epitome of Mercurius Scoticus, lately Printed at Rotterdam, 1650.
div.p: SIR, the Scotch Mist is so thick and dark, their policies so mysterious, that 'tis impossible for common eyes to pierce through into their Designes; onely now and then a Blithe blinke happens, whereby the bright face of Truth may be discerned: and such an one I have lately met with, Mercurius Scoticus, a piercing Linceus that with a curious eye hath peep'd into most of their Plots, and descry'd some secrets the world never knew before. To prevent the irksomnesse of Reading, 'tis but an Epitome I send: His maine scope is, to demonstrate by pregnat proofes, That the Scotch Presbyter never intended Charles the II. should be their King, or to espouse his quarrell, or Ingage in a Warre with the English: for the truth thereof, he appeales to the judgement of every rationall man, that will but perpend their actions both before His Majesties comming amongst them, at His arrivall, and ever since His abode there.

Before His comming into Scotland, Their Proclaiming him King, with a limitation, whereby Regall Majesty became fetter'd in the snares of the Covenant. Their most unreasonable Propositions and Demands, sent by their Commissioners to the Treaty at Breda: Their new modelling the Scotch State after the English Mode: Their barbarous murdering the Marquesse of Montrosse, His Majesties Generall, and sundry others of His most loyall Subjects: Their bannishing all the rest in whom the least sparke of loyalty appear'd: Their
stopping the mouthes of all such Ministers as affected Monarchy and hated Independency, and the Anti-monarchicall Sectaries: Their entrusting the Army and strengths of the Kingdome to the sworne Enemies of Monarchy: Their Commiting the chiefe Government both of Kirke and Kingdome to such as had lifted up their hands against the Royall Family, and by shewing themselves so active in the late Rebellion against the Father, testified to all the world their endeavours to cut off his Posterity, Root and Branch: Their sending back William Murrey into Holland (after the Marquesse of Montrosse his death) to breake off the Treaty before it was concluded; and if finished, to command their Commissioners in their name to disclaime it, as having proceeded further then either their Commission or Instructions did warrant them: and that their Commissioners by no meanes should bring home their King, for that he had Invaded the Kingdome in time of the Treaty; (which indeed was no reason at all, because in that Treaty there was no Cessation agreed on) if Mr. Murrey had arrived in Holland before His Majesties shipping for Scotland, doubtlesse the Commissioners would not have presum'd to have brought him thither.

Then at His Majesties arrivall: Their Inglorious Reception of their King, without preparation of any one of his houses, without making any provision or entertainment fit for a Prince: Their banishing all his Majesties domestick servants: Their forbidding any of the Royall party to come within 10. miles of the Court: Their Ministers impudent Preaching, their disgracefull and dishonourable Language even to His Majesties face, touching his blessed Father, and the Royall Family in their Court-Sermons.

Lastly, during his abode there, Their receiving of him to
the exercise of His Regall power, with this limitation, that he Rule according the Counsells of Kirke and Kingdome: their not putting themselves into a Posture of defence, till Generall Cromwell had entred into the Kingdome: Their not fortifying of Leeth: Their not Crowning of His Majesty, according to the Agreement at Breda: Their refusing to give fourescore Danish Officers entertainment, who landed last July at St. Andrews: their rejecting the assistance of all Forreigners whatsoever: Their Casheering of those they call Malignants, both English and Scotch, to the number of 5000. Foot and Horse: Their not setting up His Majesties Standerd: Their not permitting him to remaine in the Army: Their Publishing most dishonourable Proclamations and Declarations in His Majesties Name, together with the uncivill usage of His Majesty, even after Generall Cromwell had defeated their Army at Dunbar; the cause of which overthrow they impute to His sinnes, and the sinnes of His Fathers House. By all these Evidences it is more then manifest, 'twas never the intention of the Scotch Presbyter to establish Charles the II. in His Fathers Thron: and let the World judge, whether by these their Actions, they have not now approv'd themselves as treacherous, as the Marquesse of Montrosse privately by his Avisoes represented them to His Majestie, and Publiquely to all the World by His Declaration.

Sir, for confirmation of these truths, and your further satisfaction in every particular, I beseech you to peruse the Act of the 27. of June last, confirming the Treaty, together with all the Declarations put forth by the Scots since that month; but especially that which was set out by the Kirke, and approv'd of by the Committee of State, Aug. 13. as also the Reasons of their Fast Published the 10. of Sept. following,
where you shall finde these to bee the grounds of their ensuing Fast.

Ye are to mourne
1. For the sinnes of the Nation in-generall.
2. For the sinnes of our Commissioners, in bringing over our King so soone.
3. For accepting of the King, before he had more sufficiently Repented him of his by-past sinnes.
4. For the not purging the Army of all Malignants.
5. For the too much trusting the Arme of flesh, &c.
From these and the like Printed Declarations, you may most clearely, and assuredly collect the undenyable truth of that which Mercurius Scoticus endeavours plainely to prove by his Discourse.

list.head: Foure Reasons why the Scotch Presbyter did not Crowne Charles the 2.
list.item: First, Because it would beget in the hearts of his People a more reverend and honourable esteeme of his Majesty: for though the Coronation in it selfe be but a Ceremony; yet in the Peoples esteem it is most essentiall.

Secondly, Because at the Coronation the Nobility, Gentry, and Commons doe take the Oath of Fidelity without limitation, which would shake off the Fetters their holy Covenant hath put upon our obedience.
Thirdly, Because at the Coronation a generall pardon is granted, which would be a meanes to unite all parties, and take away all Factious Exceptions.

Fourthly, Because they could not agree whether he should be anointed, or not; the Scotch Presbyter having taught for
these many yeares, that Princes are not the Lords Anoynted: and if to be anointed, whether it should be done by the Presbyter alone, or assisted by his Ruling-Elder.

div.p: Sir: Touching the Scots Affaires, since the defeate of their Army at Dunbar, the most exact account I have met with is this; Immediately after that defeate, his Majesty prudently endeavours a Reconciliation betweene all Parties, that all his Subjects, how ever formerly divided upon severall Interests, might now unite and joyne against the Common Enemy: But the Presbyter, by Covenant a sworne Enemy to the King, and his Party, sought by all meanes to hinder this Union; and for that purpose Ker and Straughen, the two Kirk Favorites, were brought off to divide themselves, and draw away a considerable Force into the West of Scotland, a part of the Countrey well affected to the English, and not forgetting the great benefit Generall Cromwell had done them after Preston fight, in freeing them from the power and oppression of the Hamilton Forces: And this divided Party were they, who fearing the miscarriages of all Affaires both in State and Army, might bee imputed to them, according as they had justly deserved, began to cry whore first, and cast dirt in his Majesties face, to save themselves, and their owne reputation.

But the King perceiving his Royal Endeavours to bee blasted by the calumnies of some, that countermined his designes, and the dayly insolencies of the Ministery, that continually aspersed his blessed Father, and himselfe in all their Sermons, growing intollerable; besides the contempt the State put upon him, not so much as admitting him to bee present at their Debates concerning Publick Affaires, tooke up a Resolution to cast himselfe upon his Loyal Subjects (that had then newly entred an Engagement for him) chusing
rather to dye Gallantly in the field with his sword in his hand, then sit still at St. Johnston, as an Image or Shadow of a King: and watching his opportunity he passed the River of Tay, and made his escape to Clova in Angus, where the same night hee was discovered, through the negligence of some of his servants, and shortly after surprized by Robert Mongomery, and being brought back to St. Johnston, his ill usage was ten times worse then before, the Presbyter not sparing to blaspheme him to his face, and revile him in the most insolent and disgracefull manner they could invent.

Notwithstanding his Majesties surprizall, the Royal Party in the North doe not desist from their Loyal and Honourable Intentions, but make their advance Southwards, in hope by some meanes or other to effect the Kings freedome: Upon their march they heare of Sir John Brownes Regiment, and two more commanded by Colonel Maule, and Colonel Pitscotty, sent by the Kirk to suppresse them: These they encounter valiantly at Glames in Angus, and by a gallant charge rout those three Regiments; which happy Victory so animated the Nobility and Gentry of those Parts, that they unanimously rise for the King: Divers also of David Leslees Troops revolted after that fight, and betooke themselves to the right side; but it did so greatly terrifie the Kirks Party, that they presently desire a Treaty, whereto the Royal Party condescended, upon condition Hostages be given on both sides; and to bee short, my Lord Ogilvy was accepted of for the Royal Party, and Dumfernling for the Kirk.

At this Treaty the more the King and his side condescended, the more insolent grew the Kirk in their Demands; insomuch that the Treaty brake up, without satisfaction to either Part: No sooner was that dissolved, but presently the Kirk thunder out Excommunications against the Royal
Party, and nothing would appease them, till his Majesty was constrained to command Generall Middleton, the Earle of Athol, and Marquesse Huntley, to disband, which in obedience to his Majesties Authority, immediately they did.

Now the Kirk having gained the poynt they aimed at, command David Leslee, with the greatest part of his Army to march into the North of Scotland, there to recruit his broken Regiments, and to secure the persons of all Malignants; No sooner did this Newes arrive in the North (as ill Newes flies apace) but the Engagers betake themselves to their Armes, and stand upon their guard, Generall Middleton once more accepting of the Command, as well for his owne safety, as the preservation of his Majesty, and his Interest; And that he might be sure to leave no Enemy behinde his back, he presently marches Northwards, and takes in the Garrison of Straboggy, and the Bogge of Gight, two strong houses, belonging to Marquesse Huntly, thereby very much increasing his Army; with which now growne to a considerable Body, hee advanceth Southwards, resolved to fight David Leslee: but when the Armies faced each other, Leslees men began to mutiny, and refused to fight against their owne Countrey-men; This begot a Treaty, and that a friendly Accord between the Generalls; where 'twas agreed on by both parts, that all true hearted Scots, lovers of their King and Countrey, should now unite and joyne against the Common Enemy, who miserably wasted their Countrey, and had barbarously killed in coole blood, and starved divers of their Countreymen, whom they carried Prisoners into England.

list.head: The Heads of that Agreement were:
list.item: 1. That an Act of Indemnity should bee passed, which might include all persons.
2. That a free Parliament bee called, to meet towards the end of December.
3. That his Majesty bee solemnly crowned.
4. That the Kirk-men bee debarred from intermedling with Civill or Military Affaires.

div.p: Whilst these things are acting at home, there are some stirring Instruments abroad, that have endeavoured to sow some jealousies between the King and his Brother, the Duke of Yorke; and for that purpose it is thought W. M. the Kirk-Agent hath procured a Warrant from the King to bring the Duke into Scotland, that if it may serve for the Kirks advantage, they may ruine the two Brothers both at once: For I can assure you, that before the Presbyter will lose his supremacy over Princes, he will joyne with the greatest enemies of Monarchy utterly to destroy it.
Sir, I beg your pardon for creating you all this trouble, who must subscribe my selfe,

postscript.p: Sir, By the next you shall receive the rest of Mercurius Scoticus Epitomized.
